Row.Summary: The Airtel/MicroEnsure partnership aimed to introduce millions of emerging consumers to their first health insurance products by offering simple cover, for free. By introducing consumers to a basic health insurance product, MicroEnsure aimed to establish trust through transparent, reliable operations. It then offered intuitive up-sell products to allow customers to increase their coverage by paying for more cover for themselves and/or their families, which created a path to greater health insurance coverage.

A Bangladeshi social enterprise, Dnet, implements Aponjon in partnership with the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW) and with support from the US Agency for International Development. Row.Summary: During home visits, CHWs use the mobile phone based application to access audio & visual counseling modules for antenatal and postnatal care. The application also serves as a data collection tool, allowing CHWs to upload information about the pregnancy. CHW's can use the mobile tool to link a woman's family with a skilled provider once labor begins.
Row.ContactInformation: Dennis Cherian, Senior Director of Health, World Vision, Email: dcherian@worldvision.org | Meredith Crews, Child Survival and Health Grants Program, USAID, Email: mcrews@usaid.gov

Row.Funder: WHOâ€™s Innovation Working Group, UN Foundation; Concern Worldwideâ€™s Innovations for Maternal, Newborn and Child Health
Row.Summary: CCPF provides regular tips and reminders via mobile text or voice messages on reproductive, maternal and newborn health topics. Messages are tailored to the client's week of pregnancy or a child's age.

Row.CaseStudyLink: Community Led Total Sanitation Mobile Surveillance

Row.ApplicationType: Data Collection and reporting
Row.Country: Dominican Republic, Cambodia, India, Kenya, Uganda
Row.Summary: eCompliance is a portable biometric identification system operated by CHWs that is capable of identifying patients by their fingerprint and compiling patient adherence data for tuberculosis drug treatment (DOTS). CHWs are reminded via text messaging when one of their patients misses a dose.
Row.CaseStudyLocation: Cambodia, Dominican Republic, India, Kenya, Uganda
Row.ContactInformation: Yanis Ben Amor, Director of the HIV/AIDS and TB Initiative, Columbia University, Email: yba2101@columbia.edu

Row.ApplicationType: Electronic Decision Support, Sensors and point-of-care diagnostics
Row.Funder: Action Meningitis (an initiative of the Meningitis Research Foundation principally funded by the Scottish Government and Deutsche Bank)
Row.Summary: ETAT is a mobile phone based triage system used in urban health centers by Health Surveillance Assistants that allows them to scan through the queues to identify children needing immediate medical assessment. The tool tracks a child from assessment in the queue to arrival at the hospital.
Row.ContactInformation: Steve Ollis, D-tree International, Email: sollis@d-tree.org | Thomasena O'Byrne, Action Meningitis, Email: tobyrne@mlw.medcol.mw

Row.ProjectTitle: Empowering and Mobilizing People living with HIV/AIDS (EMPower II)
Row.ApplicationType: Client education and behavior change communication
Row.Summary: Platform uses bulk text messaging containing health education, HIV prevention, service and treatment messages. Subscribers are HIV+ and are able to use a call back feature to receive further counseling on minimizing transmission and other topics.
Row.ContactInformation: Huai-Ming Sun, Senior Program Officer, World Education Inc., Email: hsun@worlded.org | Emmanuel Essandoh, HIV Prevention Specialist, USAID, Email: essandoh@usaid.gov

Row.ApplicationType: Client education and behavior change communication, Electronic decision support
Row.Summary: Engage TB is a self-screening mobile application for tuberculosis. Participants do TB screening and access basic health information and TB prevention education via SMS messaging. The application also provides a list of health facilities that have the capability to do laboratory testing to confirm TB.
Row.ContactInformation: Mustafa Kudrati, Pathfinder, Email: mkudrati@pathfinder.org | Marion McNabb, Pathfinder, Email: mmcnabb@pathfinder.org

Row.ApplicationType: Data collection and reporting
Row.TechnicalHealthArea: Maternal Health, Newborn Health, Child Health
Row.Summary: A mobile data tool that was used to collect information on health facility locations, ownership status (public, private etc), opening hours and types of services provided. GPS coordinates were submitted along with facility data, thus allowing users to click on a facility's symbol on Google Maps to show the location or search for facilities by district and other variables.
Row.ContactInformation: Dr. Sohail Agha, Director M&E, MCHIP, Email: sohail.agha@jhpiego.org | Monica Villanueva, AOR, USAID/Pakistan, Email: mvillanueva@usaid.gov

Row.ProjectTitle: Grand Challenge Exploration Phase I Project
Row.ApplicationType: Client education and behavior change communication, Electronic decision support
Row.TechnicalHealthArea: Maternal Health, Newborn Health, Child Health
Row.Summary: A mobile phone based job aid used by CHWs to register pregnant women, follow prenatal and postpartum care algorithms, follow audio and text prompts through non-urgent questions and reminders and advice on ensuring a safe pregnancy.
Row.ContactInformation: Sherrie Simms, World Vision, Email: sherrie_simms@wvi.org | Joseph Torres, GCE Program Coordinator, Gates Foundation, Email: gce@gatesfoundation.org

Row.ProjectTitle: Innovation At Scale For Community Access And Lasting Effects (inSCALE)
Row.ApplicationType: Electronic Decision Support, Sensors and point-of-care diagnostics, Electronic Health Records
Row.Summary: inScale uses images and audio to train CHWs on consultation steps to assess, classify, treat and refer patients. The decision support tool includes a checklist of mild and severe signs of diarrhea, pneumonia and malaria and provides treatment guidance. The application also collects weekly case data and drug stock levels that are sent to a central server.
Row.ContactInformation: Karin Kallander, Program Coordinator, Malaria Consortium, Email: k.kallander@malariaconsortium.org | Paulin Basinga, Senior Program Officer, Gates Foundation, Email: paulin.basinga@gatesfoundation.org

Row.ApplicationType: Provider Training and Education
Row.Summary: An application that uses a interactive voice response system to deliver information and trainings to health care workers. The mLearning system can be delivered to basic mobile phones without an internet connection and is free.

Row.Funder: Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Innovation Working Group: NORAD, mHealth Alliance, United Nations Foundation, WHO, Belgium Development Agency (BTC)

Row.ContactInformation: Hilde Eugelink, Community Relations Officer, IICD, Email: heugelink@iicd.org

Row.ApplicationType: Data Collection and Reporting
Row.Funder: MACEPA, USAID, Isdell Flowers, Zambian Anglican Council
Row.Summary: A mobile phone application used by CHWs that tracks malaria cases and reports to the central DHIS2 system. CHWs diagnose and treat malaria at the village level and enter data into the application. Data is reviewed by District Health Personnel on reporting rates, commodity stocks and malaria burden indicators to monitor performance of remote clinics.

Row.ApplicationType: Client education and behavior change communication

Row.ApplicationType: Sensors and Point-of-Care Diagnostics, data collection and reporting, electronic decision support, electronic health records

Row.ApplicationType: Sensors and Point-of-Care Diagnostics, data collection and reporting

Row.Funder: African Transparency and Technology Initiative, SNV Uganda, WaterAid in Uganda
Row.Summary: M4W is a multiplatform initiative using computers and mobile phones to provide information on water points and management. The initiative aims to improve response to non-functional drinking water sources in rural areas in order to improve access to clean and safe water.

Row.ApplicationType: Client education and behavior change communication, Electronic Decision Support, Provider Training and Education
Row.Summary: Mobilise is a mobile technology that provides supportive services for domestic violence (DV) prevention. The system has 4 mHealth tools: mTrainer to build primary health care providers' knowledge & skills to address DV; mSoukhya to support HCW's with identification of and response to women experiencing violence; mShakti to raise community awareness of DV among CHW's; and mSupervise to engage supervision of HCW's and the health system response to DV
Row.ContactInformation: Suneeta Krishnan, Senior Epidemiologist, RTI International, Email: skrishnana@rti.org | Sharmila Neogi, Maternal Health Specialist, USAID, Email: sneogi@usaid.gov

Row.ApplicationType: Data collection and reporting
Row.TechnicalHealthArea: Infectious Diseases, Parasitic Diseases, malaria and other vector-borne dieseases
Row.Summary: mSOS is an SMS-based disease notification system where health care workers immediately relay information on suspected priority diseases to sub-county, county and national MOH officials. Response actions, epidemic graphs and maps are displayed on the mSOS web portal.
Row.ContactInformation: Matilu Mwau, Principal Research Officer, KEMRI, Email: mitsuru.toda@gmail.com

Row.ApplicationType: Data collection and reporting
Row.Summary: mSpray is an IRS tool used for mapping, monitoring and feedback for malaria control accessed through a web portal via smart phones/tablets. The portal displays the areas targeted for spraying including precise number of houses to be sprayed and their locations and allows for data entry and upload to cloud servers at each house.
Row.ContactInformation: Derek Pollard, IRS Program Manager, Akros, Email: dpollard@akros.com | Daniel Bridges, Director of Research, Akros, Email: dbridges@akros.com

Row.Summary: The m4Change project launched the conditional cash transfer (CCT) scheme in 2014; this system incentivizes mothers to attend maternal health services, as well as tracks patients to ensure continued care is provided.

Row.ProjectTitle: Maternal and Child Health Integrated Program, Kenya
Row.ApplicationType: Client education and behavior change communication, Data collection and reporting, Electronic decision support, Provider work planning and scheduling, Registries and vital events tracking
Row.Summary: In Kenya, failure to complete the immunization schedule by children who have previously accessed immunization services is an obstacle to ensuring that most children are fully immunized. The MCHIP Program conducted operational research to determine the reasons why children were not attending follow-up immunization appointments.
Row.ContactInformation: Lora Shimp, Senior Technical Officer, John Snow, Inc., Email: lshimp@jsi.com

Row.ProjectTitle: mCare: Enhancing Neonatal Survival in Rural South Asia
Row.ApplicationType: Client education and behavior change communication, Data collection and reporting, Electronic health records, Provider work planning and scheduling
Row.Summary: mCARE is an integrated mobile-phone and server-based software system that helps community health workers (CHWs) digitally manage their daily workflow, including systematic pregnancy surveillance, identification and registration of pregnant women, referral and emergency support, and timely and comprehensive essential newborn care.
Row.ContactInformation: Dr. Alain B. Labrique, Director, Johns Hopkins Global mHealth Initiative; Email: alabriqu@gmail.com
